step1.sentence: I decided to get my feet wet by volunteering at a local startup before launching my own business.

step2.story: Maya had always dreamed of teaching, but she had zero classroom experience. She signed up to tutor neighborhood kids on weekends just to get her feet wet. After a few sessions, she knew this was exactly the career she wanted to pursue.

step3.story: Jordan stared at the job posting for a junior software developer position. He had spent months learning to code through online courses, but he had never worked on a real project with a team. His mentor suggested he contribute to an open-source project first to get his feet wet. Nervous but determined, Jordan picked a beginner-friendly issue and submitted his first pull request. The maintainer left encouraging feedback, and within a week, his code was merged. That small victory gave him the confidence to finally hit 'Apply' on the job listing.

meaning.realUsageKo: 어떤 새로운 활동이나 분야를 본격적으로 시작하기 전에 처음으로 경험해 본다는 의미로 사용됩니다. 큰 도전 앞에서 가볍게 시도해 보는 뉘앙스입니다.
meaning.etymologyKo: 수영장이나 바다에 들어가기 전에 먼저 발끝만 물에 담가 온도를 확인하는 행동에서 유래한 표현입니다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 격식 없는 일상 대화에서 자주 쓰이며, 조심스럽지만 긍정적으로 첫 경험을 시작한다는 느낌을 줍니다. 실패 부담 없이 가볍게 시도해 보라는 격려의 뉘앙스가 있습니다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: Why don't you get your feet wet with a part-time internship first?
meaning.shortExampleKo: 먼저 파트타임 인턴십으로 경험을 쌓아 보는 게 어때?
